pdgm.pdgmnote: Lambdin1971 p. 82. These are the nom(inative) pronouns (used for subjects);dat(ive) pronouns (used for indirect objects;the preposition ʾeṯ plus suffixes);and acc(usative) pronouns (used for direct objects;the definite direct object marker ʾeṯ plus suffixes).

Full Hebr verbal words are formed by combining the stem with the corresponding affixes of the VerbSubjMarker paradigm. The equivalences between the dervStem termiology used here and traditional Hebrew dervStem terminology is as follows:B = Qal,N = Niphal,D = Piel,Du = Pual,S = Hiphil,St = Hithpael (S2t is for the prefix hišta-,as with the root ḥwy),Su = Hophal. In addition there are the reduplicating stems Polel and Polal.
Lambdin1971 p. 31;particle of existence or non-existence plus the lamed,often with pronominal suffixes,indicates possession.

Lambdin1971. The quiesced aleph(non-phonological glottal stop) is indicated by parentheses. In Lambdins transliteration on p. 119 of Introduction to Biblical Hebrew he does not represent the aleph in transliteration at all.

Lambdin1971 p. 260;Hebrew uses 3 object suffixes for the perfective and 2 suffixes for prefix forms (imperfective and jussive). * = the 2p forms are rare and were presumably –kem and –ken in each case. juss = Jussive/Short Forms (including imperative forms;imperative forms ending in a vowel drop the initial vowel -ē- in the following forms).The environments are as follows:env1 = suffix is post-consonantal and stressed (3ms and 2ms perfective forms);env2 = suffix is post-vocalic and unstressed (2fs,1cs,3cp,2m/fp,1cp perfective forms);env3 = suffix is post-consonantal and unstressed (3fs perfective forms);env4 = suffixes on Prefix Forms (the two paradigms are distributed as here as a tendency,but not as a rule)

Lambdin1971. The quiesced aleph(non-phonological glottal stop) is indicated by parentheses. In Lambdins transliteration on p. 119 of Introduction to Biblical Hebrew he does not represent the aleph in transliteration at all.
